During the Spanish Civil War, which lasted from 1936 to 1939, Spain's mountainous terrain played a vital role in both the Republican and Nationalist strategies. In the initial stages of the war, the mountains provided cover for the Republican guerrilla fighters, who were able to launch surprise attacks on Nationalist troops moving through the valleys below. This helped the Republicans to gain early momentum in the conflict.

However, as the war progressed, the Nationalists began to use the mountains to their advantage as well. General Francisco Franco, the Nationalist leader, coordinated his troops to capture strategic mountain positions and establish fortified defensive positions. This allowed the Nationalists to maintain supply lines and launch counter-attacks against Republican forces.

The rugged terrain also made it difficult for the Republicans to coordinate their attacks effectively, as communication and transportation were often slow and unreliable. This made it easier for the Nationalists, who had better communication lines and were able to coordinate their troops more effectively.

Overall, the mountainous terrain in Spain during the Civil War played a critical role in shaping military tactics and strategies for both sides, with both advantages and disadvantages.
